posts.post_content:
*"Have you read the flavor text carefully? It's a grammatical train wreck..."*  
-Enchurito.  
  
It's perfectly grammatical.  
  
"Izzet-designed conductors atop Sunhome..."--this is the subject.  
  
"...charge empty sets of armor..."--this explains what the conductors do.  
  
"that give form to the fluctuating elementals."--and this explains what those charged suits of armor do.  
  
Boiling it down, it says, "Conductors charge armor." What kind of conductors? Conductors that sit atop Sunhome and were designed by the Izzet. What kind of armor? Empty sets of it. What does the armor do? Give form to the elementals.  
  
Your suggestion, however, makes no sense. "Izzet-designed conductors atop Sunhome charged empty sets of armor give form to the fluctuating elementals"? The tenses of the verbs don't match--"charged" vs. "give form". There needs to be a coordinating conjunction between the clauses "charged empty sets of armor" and "give form...". You wouldn't say "Izzet-designed machines generated electric... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

"...charge empty sets of armor..."--this explains what the conductors do.

"that give form to the fluctuating elementals."--and this explains what those charged suits of armor do.

Boiling it down, it says, "Conductors charge armor." What kind of conductors? Conductors that sit atop Sunhome and were designed by the Izzet. What kind of armor? Empty sets of it. What does the armor do? Give form to the elementals.

Your suggestion, however, makes no sense. "Izzet-designed conductors atop Sunhome charged empty sets of armor give form to the fluctuating elementals"? The tenses of the verbs don't match--"charged" vs. "give form". There needs to be a coordinating conjunction between the clauses "charged empty sets of armor" and "give form...". This is scary and good!  
I like it, since I can respect that it's not quite "overpowered" (it IS super powerful, it can net a difference of 12 life in a single attack for 4cmc only), but still balanced enough to not make it frustrating (yeah, first strike and a simple ping does it for this guy)  
4.5/5 for being quite balanced

posts.post_content:
Conjurer's Closet and Sundial of the Infinite will only keep him around an extra turn since they both can only be used on your turn. End of your opponent's turn the Trooper is gone again. You would have him as a one shot life gain blocker though.  
  
Gift of Immortality can keep him around if done correctly. Beginning of the end step, the Spark Trooper dies. Gift gets triggered in response to him hitting the graveyard and he comes back into play immediately. Since the Trooper dies at the beginning, and not just before the beginning of the end step, Gift's triggered rules says it comes back at the next end step, which would be your opponent's turn. So the Trooper stays around and waits for the beginning of the next end step. At that point, both he and the Gift trigger. Choose to have Gift resolve first and then the Trooper dies and retriggers the Gift. Same thing would happen if the Trooper has the Gift during main phase and died in combat.  
  
The downside of this is that the Troope... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

Gift gets triggered in response to him hitting the graveyard and he comes back into play immediately. Since the Trooper dies at the beginning, and not just before the beginning of the end step, Gift's triggered rules says it comes back at the next end step, which would be your opponent's turn. So the Trooper stays around and waits for the beginning of the next end step. At that point, both he and the Gift trigger. Choose to have Gift resolve first and then the Trooper dies and retriggers the Gift. Same thing would happen if the Trooper has the Gift during main phase and died in combat.

[Exava](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Exava)  
[Burning Earth](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Burning Earth)  
[Chandra, Pyromaster](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Chandra, Pyromaster)
